messages.content:
create a webvr scene with this image as the skybox: https://i.redd.it/9jysz3xh8p501.jpg
Make sure everything is in a single HTML file with embedded CSS and JS in a single code block to be used as a web app.

Hereâ€™s a simple example of a WebVR scene with the provided image as a skybox. This example uses A-Frame, an easy-to-use framework for building WebVR experiences. The code is placed in a single HTML file with embedded CSS and JS.

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>WebVR Scene</title>
    <script src="https://aframe.io/releases/1.2.0/aframe.min.js"></script>
    <style>
        body { margin: 0; }
        a-scene { height: 100vh; }
    </style>
</head>
<body>
    <a-scene>
        <a-sky src="https://i.redd.it/9jysz3xh8p501.jpg" rotation="0 -130 0"></a-sky>
        <a-entity position="0 1.6 -4">
            <a-box position="-1 0.5 0" rotation="0 45 0" color="#4CC3D9"></a-box>
            <a-sphere position="1 0.5 0" radius="0.5" color="#EF2D5E"></a-sphere>
            <a-cylinder position="0 0.5 1" radius="0.2" height="1.5" color="#FFC65D"></a-cylinder>
            <a-plane position="0 0 -4" rotation="-90 0 0" width="4" height="4" color="#7BC8A4"></a-plane>
        </a-entity>
        <a-entity camera look-controls position="0 1.6 0"></a-entity>
    </a-scene>
</body>
</html>
```

### Instructions to Use:
1. Copy the entire code above into a text editor.
2. Save the file with a `.html` extension, for example, `webvr_scene.html`.
3. Open the saved file in a web browser that supports WebVR (like Chrome or Firefox).
4. If you have a VR headset compatible with WebVR, you can enter VR mode by clicking the VR button that appears in the bottom right corner of the A-Frame scene.

### Note:
Ensure your browser supports WebVR or WebXR features. If you don't have a VR headset, you can still explore the scene in normal 2D mode!
